The Sweetest Girl in the World.
By A, W.

DRAMATIS PERSONAE.
Mr. Conrad Dulaney, who has a Secret to
tell.
Miss Imogen Howard, who listens to the
Secret.
Scene: A modern drawing room opening
into a conservatory. Near the mantel is a
small tea table prettily set. A chair and a
settle covered with fancy cushions are close
by. Flowers, plants, bric-a-brac are scattered in artistic confusion throughout the
room.
Time: Five o'clock, winter afternoon.
Miss Imogen Howard (sitting by tea table
nervously arranging and re-arranging the
tea paraphernalia)—I suppose it had to
come. It is the way of all flirtations, and
I have simply been doing the summer girl
act. The beautiful times are over. No
more sitting on the rocks at Bar Harbor; no
more luncheons at the Casino at Narragansett; and oh, dear! it meant nothing, absolutely nothing—the lovely moonlight sails
that . worried mamma so—I have shocked
Aunt Ann in vain, and endangered my
Christmas gift in that quarter for shortlived pleasure. And now the end has come,
and I have to brace up and congratulate
him upon his engagement to that hateful,
painted-up little doll, Nancy King! He will
be here soon; it is nearly five. Better read
his note again and be prepared for the worst.
(Takes a note from the table and reads.)
"My dear Miss Howard: May I drop in for
my long promised cup of tea this afternoon,
and will you listen to me? I have a secret
to tell you—perhaps you have guessed it. I
am in love with the sweetest girl in the
world. You know well whom I mean without words, and I hope, I pray before the day

is finished to become engaged to her. If I
do not hear to the contrary I will be with
you at five, and oh! dear Miss Howard I beg,
think mercifully of me. Ever yours devotedly, Conrad Dulaney." "Dear Miss Howard"
indeed! Last summer I was the "Fair Imogen." Such is life! But I hear the bell.
I will face the music. At least, he shall not
say that I am wearing the willow, but I
wonder what he sees in that little, nasty,
idiot, Nancy King—yet report declares that
he is with her constantly. (Stuffs note
under the sofa _pillow and assumes a dignified attitude).
(Portiere swung aside and enter Mr. Conrad Dulaney. He holds out both hands)—
My dear Miss Howard—Miss Imogen, this
is joy.
Miss Howard takes only one hand and
coldly motions him to a seat at the opposite
side of the table.
Mr. Dulaney (feeling snubbed)—I---you
see I am here—you received my note?
Miss Howard (indifferently)—Your note!
oh yes, asking if I would be at home this
afternoon; you know I always am, at this
hour.
Mr. Dulaney (aside)—By Jove! how unconcerned. (Aloud)—But, Miss Imogen, I
hoped that you would give orders to admit
me alone.
Miss Howard—Why, really, Mr. Dulaney,
one cannot very well give out generally that
one is at home at five, and then refuse admittance to anybody; can one?
Mr. Dulaney—Under some circumstances.
I wanted particularly to see yau this afternoon.
Miss Howard (demurely)—And so, perhaps, might others.
Mr. Dulaney—Doubtless, but still—Oh!
dear, Miss Howard, you surely remember
last summer. Think of our two heavenly

2

THE NEWS-LETTER.

weeks at Bar harbor! and of my following
you to Narragansett. Think of—
Miss Howard (interrupting)—Yes, I cannot soon forget Bar Harbor; it is just the
place for a generally all-round good time.
So many men! I wonder what becomes of
them in the winter?
Mr. Dulaney (sarcastically)—Frozen stiff,
poor devils, by the summer girls when they
meet again!
Miss Howard (indignantly)—How I hate
that term, "summer girl." It only means
someone with whom to flirt.
Mr. Dulaney—More probably someone who
does the flirting. Does it not?
Miss Howard (argumentatively) — Not
necessarily; but I despise the expression, it
is so hackneyed. More monotonous even
than "fin-du-seicle" or "up-to-date."
Mr. Dulaney—Pardon me for using it then.
But, Miss Howard, you give me small encouragement to tell you the secret that is
trembling upon my lips.
Miss Howard (pretending surprise)—The
secret? Yes, you mentioned you had one.
But I thought that it was man's perogative
to keep secrets, while only woman loved to
tell.
Mr. Dulaney—Some secrets are never
pleasant save when enjoyed with another.
Miss Howard—You limit the enjoyment.
A secret to be thoroughly appreciated should
be told to at least a dozen, always with the
injunction "never breathe it to a soul."
Mr. Dulaney—But at all events some secrets must be shared by two at first, must
they not?
Miss Howard (aside)—It is coming; I
must brace up. (Aloud)—I suppose so; but
why tell a third?
Mr. Dulaney (confused)—A third? I
don't understand. But, Imogen, you are so
different—so strange.
Miss Howard—"Imogen!" Pray, Mr. Dulaney, when did I lose my surname?
Mr. Dulaney—Excuse me; surely when we
took our moonlight sails you allowed me
the privilege of calling you by that dear
name, "Imogen." And I, too, was only
Conrad,
Miss Howard (scornfully)—How reminiscent you have become. You remind me
of Aunt Ann: "In such and such a year we
did thus and so."

Mr. Dulaney (angrily)—Thanks; knowing
the opinion you have of your aunt, I am
flattered, I am sure.
Miss Howard (also angrily)—What opinon have I of my aunt? Well, truly, Mr.
Dulaney, is it good taste to abuse my relations or discuss my likes or dislikes?
Mr. Dulaney—Again I ask your pardon.
It seems to be the only thing that you allow
me to ask this afternoon.
Miss Howard (making a brave struggle
to be funny)—Oh! ask for a cup of tea. I
am afraid I have not been very hospitable.
I should have offered it at once; see the
water boils nicely.
Mr. Dulaney—Thanks, very much; I never
take tea.
Miss Howard (forgetting her role)—You
told me at Narragansett that you perfectly
adored tea, and that you would often drop
in for it this winter on your way up town
from the office.
Mr. Dulaney (much pleased)—You do remember Narragansett, then?
Miss Howard (recovering herself)—Yes,
surely; I met Charlie Kidder there, don't
you know? and he was devoted to me.
Mr. Dulaney (losing his self-control fearfully)—Dash Charlie Kidder! Oh I do
hope that you did not hear me. Pardon
again, but I so thoroughly despise that chap,
a regular sissy with his feminine voice and
his vivid waistcoats and gorgeous ties!
Miss Howard (trying to look severe)—I
did hear your horrible language, and consider that it is most fortunate that Aunt Ann
is not about.
Mr. Dulaney (smiling)—There I agree
with you; but Miss Imogen, don't be cross
Miss Howard (staving off the news till she
has fortified herself with another cup of tea)
—Oh! by the way, are you interested in
politics, and for whom will you vote?
Mr. Dulaney (amazed at the change of
subject)—Surely every man is in these days:
but I did not know that you cared. Last
summer you used to assure me that a good
bicycle or a stylish modiste was of far more
consequence than a good President.
Miss Howard (coyly)—That was before I
met Mr. Du Pine. You know he is a great
gun in his party, and he has been coaching
me.

THE NEWS-LETTER.
Mr. Dulaney (jealously)—Du Pine! Does
that old fossil visit you? He ought to be
preparing for another and a better world.
Miss Howard (pleased to have provoked
wrath)—Well, really, is visiting me a bar
to future happiness? So like a man to make
fun of any one cleverer than himself. Now
I never get angry when I hear of a woman'
who is better looking.
Mr. Dulaney (happily)—You never hear
of one.
Miss Howard (much appeased)—Thanks;
you shall have three lumps of sugar and
five pieces of lemon for your politeness.
Mr. Dulaney (laughing)—Spare me. But,
11!Iiss Howard, won't you listen to my secret,
or have you guessed it?
Miss Howard (with dignity)—It is not
hard to guess what the whole town is discussing.
Mr. Dulaney (surprised) — The whole
town! Why, Imogen—
Miss Howard—Again I must remind you
that I am only "Imogen" to my family and
dearest friends.
Mr. Dulaney (mortified)—Kidder and Du
Pine, I suppose. I can only beg your forgiveness for my presumption, yet, Miss Howard, you have changed towards me; now
last summer—
Miss Howard—Still harping upon last
summer. Is the present nothing, Mr. Dulaney, that you should forever dwell upon
the past?
Mr. Dulaney (epigrammatically) — The
past often times makes the present.
Miss Howard—Did you get that out of a
book, or make it up? It sounds like Mr.
Du Pine.
Mr. Dulaney (in a temper)—Unfortunately, I "made it up,' as you say; but if it suggests that ass Du Pine, I will promise you
never to repeat it.
Miss Howard (meditatively)—If it was
not too ridiculous, I should imagine that
you were jealous.
Mr. Dulaney (gloomily)—I have no right
to be jealous, have I?
Miss Howard (stiffly)—I am sure I do not
know what rights you have.
Mr. Dulaney (rising)—Well, it is useless
to prolong this conversation; I see that you
do not wish me to speak.
Miss Howard (aside)—He must not think

3

that; I must be brave. (Aloud)—Indeed, you
are mistaken; I wish very much to hear your
secret. You said that you were in love and
hoped soon to be engaged to the "sweetest
girl in the world." Of course, it is easy to
tell who she is—
Mr. Dulaney (coming nearer)—Of course
it is; and does she love me, do you think?
Miss Howard (endeavoring to steady her
voice)—I fancy so. They say that she is
not hard to please, and that she has been
trying to become engaged for an age.
Mr. Dulaney (appalled at her candor)—
Really! (aside)—Confound it, I don't understand her; is she making fun of me?
Miss Howard (recovering herself and
smiling)—Dear Mr. Dulaney, I must not be
so unamiable. I know that Nancy King is
an angel in disguise and deserves your love.
Mr. Dulaney (utterly amazed)—Nancy
King! What has she to do with my love,
and why drag her into this discussion?
Miss Howard (more utterly amazed)-0h,
is she not the chief motif of it?
Mr. Dulaney (realizing the truth at last)
—Why, my darling, my beloved, did you
think that I was writing of and talking about
Nancy King when I used the expression the
"sweetest girl in the world?"
Miss Howard (too realizing the truth at
last and blushing)—I—
Mr. Dulaney (coming forward and holding
out his arms)—Little goose!
Miss Howard (laughing)—The "sweetest
girl in the world," don't you mean?

THE NEWS-LETTER.

THE BALTIMORE CONCERT.
The date of the Musical Clubs' concert has
at last been definitely announced, posters are
out, tickets are on sale, and everyone on the
clubs is engaged in putting on the extra
finishing touches which are necessary for the
most important concert of the season. At
any time of day the passer-by may hear the
strains of fair music proceeding from the
windows of McCoy or Hopkins Halls, for the
clubs are practicing almost continuously.
The Glee Club is in excellent shape; this
year's aggregation numbers some of the best
voices that have ever been at Hopkins, and
the songs are particularly good. Among
them are:"The University Ode," with which
the concert will probably open; an old English ballad, entitled "A Franklynne's Dogge
Jumped Over a Style," which possesses much
attraction; "Hoo Wah Hoo, or the Tale of
the Western Desperado," to say the least,
exciting; "Jenks' Compound;" a stein song
by Mendelssohn, and a number of others. A
quartette, consisting of Messrs. Adkins,
Haughton, Holmes, and Ruth will be a feature; and it is said that Mr. Bristol has a
surprise in the way of some new song
"stunts."
The Mandolin Club has a repertoire no
less varied than that of the Glee Club: the
1905 Medley, which contains a little of everything that has caught the popular ear this
winter— "Katunka," "Blue Bell," "Uncle
Sammy," and many others. In addition to
the regular members of the club, Mr. Snowden has consented to drum the drum, Mr.
Ruth will try the triangle and Mr. Whittle
will flute the flute and blow the French horn.
The resulting orchestral effects should be
highly pleasing.
It was very unfortunate last year that the
fire occurred just before the concert; for a
time, indeed, things looked as if there would
be no concert at all. No such disturbing
circumstances have arisen this year, however,
and there is every reason to believe that the
coming event will be a great success.
As usual, the support of the alumni as
well as of the students is solicited. At the
time of the University of Virginia concert
here this spring, the active co-operation of
the Maryland alumni of that University was

noteworthy. Hopkins graduates, dwelling
under the very shadow of the Alma Mater,
should not prove less loyal.

DEBATE WITH BROWN
The eyes of the student body are eagerly
focused upon the date of April 8, when the
Black and Blue standard will be raised
against the forces of two leading universities.
In the afternoon our doughty twelve will
match their physical strength against that
of the University of Pennsylvania lacrosse
squad, while in the evening, in McCoy Hall,
the Hopkins debaters will meet Brown University upon the rostrum.
It will be remembered that we defeated
Brown last year in debate, but as the latter
is confident of wresting the laurels from us
this year, the coming contest will doubtless
be a spirited one. The question to be discussed is the same as that which was argued
in the inter-class debate, viz.: "Resolved,
That the economic and political interests of
the United States demand the permanent retention of the Philippine Islands."
Upon that occasion the audience and
judges were convinced by the winning
Juniors that an affirmative view should be
taken of this question, and it is "up to" our
team, in the coming debate, to reverse this
conviction, since we now have the negative
side. The men selected to represent Hopkins have already won their spurs. They
are: Messrs. Thomas De C. Ruth, Joseph T.
Singewald, L. Edwin Goldman (chairman),
and Ormond W.Hammond,alternate (sec'y).
The Brown team will consist of: Messrs.
George Hurley, Frederick Eugene Hawkins,
George Gershon Shor, and Lester Leopold,
Falk, alternate. The New Englanders will
reach Baltimore about noon Friday, and will
leave for home on Sunday.
Each debater will speak twice, the negative, instead of the affirmative, leading off
in the second round. Mr. French has been
working hard with our men ever since the
inter-class debate, and he shares the general
confidence that the team will put up a good
fight.
An attractive program of catchy selections
has been arranged by the Musical Clubs,
with which to intersperse the weighty de-

liberations of the speakers. Extra care (and
extra funds) will be used to have the hall
tastefully decorated, as the occasion will be
a social event. More palms will be used and
in many ways the display will differ from the
usual arrangements.

BALLADE OF HELEN.
Where is the heart of Helen dear,
Whose eyes my very soul ensnare,
Whose parted lips so sweet appear,
That Cupid seems enshrined there;
Where comes the brilliance of her hair,
That swiftly steals my heart away;
Oh, tell me, Fairest of the Fair,
. Where is the heart of Helen gay?

UNIVERSITY NOTES.
Dr. Jacob H. Hollander, who was appointed special commissioner to Santo Domingo
by President Roosevelt, sailed from New
York on Saturday, April 1, for San Juan.
He will return to Baltimore about the middle
of May for the benefit of the students under
him, who are to take their final examinations
in June for their degrees in Philosophy. Dr.
Barnett will take charge of Dr. Hollander's
classes during his absence.

Dr. Daniel C. Gilman represented the University at the recent dinner of the Yale
Alumni. Several members of the Hopkins
faculty were present at the banquet.

EDITORIAL.
It is to be doubted if many of the persons
who have been charmed during the past fortnight by Dr. Woodberry's lectures know
that the course which they have been attending is part of one of the world's greatest
foundations for lectures on poetry. The
Turnbull foundation ranks at least second in
the English-speaking world—perhaps it
would be safe to say the world at large. Only
a similar foundation at Oxford University
can claim to be the peer of the Turnbull
lectureship, and this surpasses it only in
point of age. Though the Turnbull foundation is a comparatively recent one, it has already advanced to a commanding position.
To be asked to deliver the annual series is an
honor which any literateur of the world
would count a distinction.
The able way in which Mr. Woodberry has
filled the position this year is proof of the
wisdom of the authorities in choosing him.
Dr. Woodberry is himself a poet of no mean
ability, as one of his poems, printed elsewhere in this issue, will prove. With the
intuition of the poet he combines the clear
insight and broad grasp of subject of the
trained critic; and his course has proved well
worthy to take its place among the illustrious
courses which have preceded it.
Although the two games which have been
played by the baseball nine have not been
especially encouraging yet, on the whole, the
prospects for a good team seem fairly bright.

The opening game was hardly a just test,
from the fact that it was the first time that
the men had played together out of doors.
In spite of this, the nine showed up to good
advantage, and won by a comfortable score.
The second game was a decided disappointment, for although Hopkins seemed to experience more than her share of bad luck,
yet the result can not be accounted for in this
way. Individual play was as much to blame
as lack of team work, and the men seemed to
be "off their game," so to speak. However,
it is much better for a slump to occur at the
beginning of the season, when it can be rectified, than at the end. The material at
Hopkins for a winning nine is for the most
part good, and a little more outdoor practice
will doubtless round out the team into excellent shape. The pitcher's box is a matter which is still giving some worry, so the
outlook will be much brighter when it is
satisfactorily decided. The team has a long
schedule before it, yet on the whole, it seems
to be quite probable that it will be a successful one.
The prospects for the Musical Clubs next
year have not hitherto seemed very bright;
it was difficult to see how any of the clubs
were to be kept up to the present standard,
and the very existence of the Banjo Club
seemed to be a matter of doubt. In such
a state of affairs it is with a decided feeling
of hopefulness that most of the under-graduates will read the letter on the subject in
this issue from Manager Pagon, who takes
a more optimistic view of the outlook. By
calculating up the players from various
sources who will compose the Mandolin and
Glee Clubs next winter, he reaches the conclusion that the Mandolin Club should be
at least as large as it is this year, and that
the prospects for the Glee Club are even
better.
With the Banjo Club conditions are not
so promising, however, and its future seems
to be in the hands of the Freshmen. Only
one man will be left in the club when the
practice begins next fall, so that the only
way that the club can be kept up is by several men taking lessons on the banjeaurine
during the summer. "There are," Mr.
Pagon says, "at least eleven men on the
other two Clubs who would find it very little

7

THE NEWS-LETTER.
trouble to take lessons on the banjeaurine.
Indeed, they should be made to do so—and
no undergraduate should be allowed to go
on the trips unless he belongs to at least
two clubs."
This is an admirable suggestion, and if
matters can be so arranged as to make these
men learn to play the banjeaurine and also
to encourage several Freshmen to learn to
play the same instrument, the success of the
next year's Banjo Club is assured. A slight
difficulty is encountered in the fact that if
the rule is made that no one shall be taken
on the trips unless he belongs to at least
two clubs, it will tend to discourage any of
the present Freshman class who might be
Inclined to take lessons on the banjeaurine
this summer from doing so, if they did not
already play another instrument. But the
advantages from such a rule would probably
outweigh the disadvantages, and we recommend it for consideration to the powers that
govern the output of musical talent at the
University.

Y. M. C. A.
At the second biennial conference of the
Associations in Maryland, Delaware and the
District of Columbia, held at Annapolis,
March 24-26, Johns Hopkins was represented
by eleven delegates. The conference was a
most successful one; and each delegate of
the total one hundred and fifty could get
something for his own benefit. The delegates
were royally entertained in the Annapolis
homes, and found this one of the best features of the conference. A special session
for college men was held Saturday afternoon.
Other meetings put the college men in touch
with the Association work in other departments. The most notable addresses were
those of Governor Warfield and Rev. John
Timothy Stone. The Hopkins delegates
were: Boyer, Bird, Fenby, Gould, Glenn and
Lips, of 1907; Curley, Gressitt and Middleton, of 1906; and Glocker and Addison, of
the graduate department. Ask any one of
them for impressions of the conference.
The committee on the Northfield Student
Conference is now beginning work, with W.
R. Straughn, '05, as chairman. Northfield,
a quaint New England village, with an edu-

cational institution known throughout our
land, is situated in the northwestern part of
Massachusetts, about twenty-four hours' distance from Baltimore. It is an ideal place
for conferences, and for many summers past,
the great student conference, with delegates
from all the leading institutions of our Eastern States, has been held there. Last year,
over six hundred were in attendance. The
opportunities open to one who is a member
of such a convention, the advantages of association with so many of the leaders in all
branches of college activity, the ten days'
life in camp, the spiritual and physical recreation afforded—all these things will the
committee set before the student body at an
early date.
The conference will take place this year
June 30 to July 9, inclusive. Every student
who believes in religious work should consider Northfield before completing his plans
for the coming summer. Yale sends more
than a hundred men each year; Harvard
sends fifty to seventy; Pennsylvania, about
forty. Cannot fifteen or twenty Hopkins
men find time to take advantage of this opportunity ?
Watch for further announcements.

ACE HIGH.
The king of hearts had a daughter,
The queen of hearts was she;
And over all of her subjects,
She ruled most graciously.'
Now the knave of hearts was her lover,
And a lover fond was he;
But the king ruled over his daughter,
And ruled most cruelly.
"I can take them both," said the father,
"Send each to far different parts;
No more can they love each other,
I win," cried the king of hearts.
But in spite of his firm refusal,
The queen and the knave eloped;
And the end of the match was lovely
—Much better than either had hoped.
Yes, the end of the match was lovely,
No danger they had to face;
For now that the pair were one, you see,
The king was ruled by the ace!

THE NEWS-LETTER.

HOPKINS, 13; ROCK HILL, 2.
The baseball season began auspiciously on
Saturday, March 25, with an easy victory
over Rock Hill College, by 13 to 2 A large
party of rooters accompanied the team to
Ellicott City, and if appearances count for
anything, got considerable pleasure out of
the trip, though the contest itself was never
close enough to produce "excitement's blissful thrill."
Hopkins practically won the game in the
first inning. MacGuinness, Rock Hill's pitching "star," appeared to have slipped his
orbit at the start, and before he settled down
Hopkins had rolled up eight runs. After
that, runs were "no object," and the five
which were afterward added to the University's score were the result of chance rather
than of purpose.
The chief interest to Hopkins rooters lay
in the fact that the game furnished an excellent opportunity for judging of the ability
of the various candidates for the team. The
fine pitching of Waring and Higgins firnished especial cause for satisfaction. It had
been feared that the nine this year would be
weak in the box, but the showing of these
two twirlers effectually dispelled this fear.
Waring pitched the first seven innings and
allowed but three hits, all of which would
have been easy outs on a better diamond.
Higgins, who was in the box the last two
innings, struck out four men in this short
time and allowed but one hit, also due to
the grounds.
Lyon made a beautiful play in the seventh,
with a one-hand catch of a wild throw to
third. Brown, at first base, was a tower of
strength, accepting thirteen chances without.

an error. Captain McDonnell fully lived up
to his reputation both in the field and at bat.
Randall played a strong and heady game behind the plate, while Bowie put up his usual
good game at third. Iglehart and Goldman
did so well in center and left fields respectively that they were given these positions
permanently. Preston had no chances in
right field, but proved somewhat of a disappointment at bat. The batting, indeed of the
whole team was below what it should have
been, due in large measure, perhaps, to the
lack of necessity to make runs.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

ST. JOHNS, 10; HOPKINS, 7.
The Hoodoo which always lurks about the
athletic field at St. John's College upon the
occasions of Hopkins visits thither, made its
usual appearance last Saturday and achieved
its usual success. Last spring St. John's
won out in the ninth inning; last fall its
eleven scored the touchdown which won
from Hopkins in the last thirty seconds of
play. This time the eighth inning witnessed
the advent of the Hoodoo.
At the beginning of this inning the score
stood 7 to 5 in favor of Hopkins. Waring
appeared invincible and the game seemed
certainly won. Then the Hoodoo took a
.hand. Four errors followed each other in
grim procession; Waring was seized with a
panic and struck two batters; then St. John's
awoke to its opportunities and "added wreck
to ruin" by smashing out a single and a
three-bagger. Five runs was the net result
of the stampede. The best Hopkins could
do in the sole inning which remained was to
go out in one, two, three order. Verily, we
had "met the enemy and we were their'n'
the Hoodoo's.
Sonie persons who saw the game were inclined to believe that the real name of the
Hoodoo was Demoralization. It may be so,
but the NEws-LETTER's "correspondent at
the front" does not believe so. There was
a child-like simplicity and lack of purpose
about the whole thing which to his mind
was inevitably suggestive of the supernatural. Past experience strengthens this view,
and loyalty applauds it. The NEWS-LETTER
still holds the high opinion of the nine to
which the Rock Hill victory gave rise. But
mind, gentlemen of the diamond, no more
Hoodoos!

LACROSSE OUTLOOK.
Johns Hopkins is on the eve of another
lacrosse season. Never in the history of our
connection with the game has the actual
strength of the team been so much a matter
of speculation as it is this year. Until the
first game has been played even the coaches
will have hardly more than an incomplete
idea upon this head.
The reason for this lies in the fact that
such a large proportion of the men will be
new. . Out of last year's twelve, only five
men—Blanck, Meyer, Dill, Morse and Strob-

9

har—will again be in the line-up. Of course,
the veteran "Bill" Schmeisser is by no
means a "new man," but the fact remains
that half at least, of the positions will have
to be filled by men who never played on a
'Varsity team before. The squad as a whole
has showed up well in practice, however, and
the large infusion of new blood may not
prove a permanent weakness.
The personnel of the team is also a matter
of guess-work. The large number of the
candidates has made the task of selecting the
team a difficult one, and the coaches have
thought it best to go very slowly in so important a particular. The exact line-up for
the opening game will scarcely be known
until the men make their appearance on the
field; and this line-up is not expected to remain through the season unaltered.
One thing, at least, however, should be
very plain to all. That is that every student is expected to attend every game.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

AN OPEN LETTER.
Wednesday, March 15, 1905.
[To the Editors of the NEWS-LETTER.]
Gentlemen:—
I have often heard it said that next year
the Musical Clubs will be very poor owing to
the lack of players. But the scarcity of men
will not be so great as has been thought. The
Glee Club will lose only three men, leaving
twenty-two to start the year with. Out of
this year's Mandolin Club fifteen men will
be back. But the prospects of the Club are
even better than would seem to be indicated
by this. In the Junior and Freshman
classes are four or five men who for some
reason or other, have not come out this year,
but who play fairly well. In the Medical
School is one man who led the club at Yale,
and another who led the Bowdoin Club, besides a number who have played at Yale,
Princeton, and elsewhere. In addition to
these are four or five players at the Latin
School who expect to enter this June. These,
with the old men, will make up a club of
twenty-five or twenty-six men, which is as
large as the Club this year. There is, evidently, therefore, no need of worrying over
the Mandolin and Glee Clubs. With the
Banjo Club, however, conditions are different, for next year only one man will be left.
Yet this is not an insurmountable difficulty,
for two years ago the same conditions existed and were overcome. Only one man
was left prom the year before. But during
the spring and summer four Juniors took
lessons on the banjeaurine, and the five, together with one Freshman and one graduate
of the year before, have made up the Club
for two years. There is no reason why this
cannot be repeated. In the other two Clubs
are at least eleven men who would find it
very little trouble to take lessons on the banjeaurine or the guitar during the summer.
Indeed, they should be made to do so, and
no undergraduate should be allowed to go
on any of the different trips unless he belongs to at least two clubs. These eleven
men could make a club every bit as good
as the one this year if they would only work.
If need be the trustees of the University
might be asked for fifty or seventy-five, dollars with which to pay a teacher.

But whatever is done, have a Banjo Club,
even though it consists of only five or six
men. A small club that plays well is every
bit as good as a large one that plays poorly.
In the year 1892 the Mandolin Club consisted of .only four men: two mandolins, one
banjo and one guitar. But there is no need
of having a small club, for if every one will
work, a club of fifteen or sixteen can be
gotten together which will be all the better
for the work having been expended in building it up.
Sincerely Yours,
W. WATTERS PAGON.

IRRESISTABLE.
Oh I wrote a poem to Polly,
And another one to Bess,
And I made some verse for Molly,
And again some more for Tess;
Oh a sonnet did for Letty,
And a rondel sweet for Nell,
And a quatrain short for Hetty,
And a song for Isabel;
Yet although they liked my powers,
In the most poetic arts,
Yet the man who sent them flowers,
Was the man that won their hearts.
—Saw I flowers growing cheaper,
Thought that I would go down deeper.
So no more I write to Polly,
And no more to pretty Bess,
So no verses send to Molly,
And no rhymes to winsome Tess;
So no sonnets make for Letty,
And no rondels sweet for Nell,
So no quatrains short for Hetty,
And no songs for Isabel;
Yet they say that I'm a "dandy,"
Know full well the best of arts,
—Now the man that sends them candy,
Is the man that wins their hearts.
'06.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

THE MEDICAL SCHOOL.
The Trustees have elected Dr. Lewellys
Franklin Barker to be Professor of Medicine.
Professor Barker is a native of Canada and
graduated in medicine in the University of
Toronto in 1890. The following year he
held the position of House Officer in the
Toronto General Hospital, and he was then
successively an assistant physician and assistant resident pathologist in the Johns
Hopkins Hospital. He was Fellow in Anatomy in the University for two years, Associate and Associate Professor of Anatomy
from 1894 to 1899, and Associate Professor
of Pathology during the year 1899-1900. In
1899 he visited the Philippine Islands as one
of the Medical Commissioners representing
this University. During the past five years
he has held the post of Professor and head of
the Department of Anatomy in the University of Chicago and in the Rush Medical College. In 1901 he was appointed by the Secretary of the Treasury a member of the
special commission to determine the existence or non-existence of plague in San Francisco.
His published works include "The Nervous System and its Constituent Neurones,"
a translation of Werner Spalteholz's "Hand
Atlas of Human Anatomy," and numerous
monographs and addresses.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

Notes From All the Colleges.
That Japan is strictly up to date pretty
much everyone is willing to admit, but it
has gotten further than most people suspect.
The island has a baseball association, and the
team of the Waseda University has won the
championship. Not content with a national
championship, the team is looking for other
worlds to conquer, and has challenged the
team of the Stanford University for a series
of games to be played in San Francisco. It
even looks as if the games may be arranged,
and if Waseda can make a good showing
it will receive the congratulations of the
American people. Baseball is thoroughly
American, exclusively, we should say, were
it not rash to attempt to prejudge what the
versatile and athletic Japanese have been
able to do with the Waseda nine.
—Intercollegiate.

In spite of an increase of 13 per cent, in
student attendance within the last year, the
University of Pennsylvania is beginning to
experience the same difficulty as Harvard
and Yale in making its fixed income and
gifts meet the running expenses.
Considerable discussion has been aroused
at the University of Pennsylvania over a bill
introduced in the State Legislature making
college hazing a misdemeanor. The university has already made every member of the
sophomore and freshman classes sign an
agreement, as a part of their matriculation,
not to participate in hazing.

The quarter-decennial class book of the class
of 1878, of Yale, just published, repeats the
evidence that academic married couples fail
By the provision of the will of the late to reproduce themselves in the census. The
John C. Coombs, class of 1869, Bowdoin has 97 marriages in the class are represented by
the promise of a substantial bequest, prob- only 179 living children.
ably aggregating $100,000.
The cost of college athletics is always a
subject in order. Interesting light is cast
on the subject by the report of the Yale
financial union, showing that at that institution last year $75,174 was expended in
connection with athletic events. Of this,
football required $26,996; baseball, $15,179;
the boat club, $16,626; the athletic association, $7,221, and maintenance of grounds,
$9,150. Despite this heavy outlay, the athletic association closed the season with a
balance of $31,222, football proving the
greatest winner, with a net profit of $44,000.

The State College of Pennsylvania has a
national bank. One hundred and five depositors have opened accounts amounting to
$18,100.
"Jiu Jitsu" has been taken up quite extensively at the University of Pennsylvania,
and a course in this science has been made
compulsory at Annapolis.
Andrew Carnegie has donated $16,700 to
St. John's College for the building of a new
laboratory.

The Sweetest Girl in the World.
By A, W.

DRAMATIS PERSONAE.
Mr. Conrad Dulaney, who has a Secret to
tell.
Miss Imogen Howard, who listens to the
Secret.
Scene: A modern drawing room opening
into a conservatory. Near the mantel is a
small tea table prettily set. A chair and a
settle covered with fancy cushions are close
by. Flowers, plants, bric-a-brac are scattered in artistic confusion throughout the
room.
Time: Five o'clock, winter afternoon.
Miss Imogen Howard (sitting by tea table
nervously arranging and re-arranging the
tea paraphernalia)—I suppose it had to
come. It is the way of all flirtations, and
I have simply been doing the summer girl
act. The beautiful times are over. No
more sitting on the rocks at Bar Harbor; no
more luncheons at the Casino at Narragansett; and oh, dear! it meant nothing, absolutely nothing—the lovely moonlight sails
that . worried mamma so—I have shocked
Aunt Ann in vain, and endangered my
Christmas gift in that quarter for shortlived pleasure. And now the end has come,
and I have to brace up and congratulate
him upon his engagement to that hateful,
painted-up little doll, Nancy King! He will
be here soon; it is nearly five. Better read
his note again and be prepared for the worst.
(Takes a note from the table and reads.)
"My dear Miss Howard: May I drop in for
my long promised cup of tea this afternoon,
and will you listen to me? I have a secret
to tell you—perhaps you have guessed it. I
am in love with the sweetest girl in the
world. You know well whom I mean without words, and I hope, I pray before the day

is finished to become engaged to her. If I
do not hear to the contrary I will be with
you at five, and oh! dear Miss Howard I beg,
think mercifully of me. Ever yours devotedly, Conrad Dulaney." "Dear Miss Howard"
indeed! Last summer I was the "Fair Imogen." Such is life! But I hear the bell.
I will face the music. At least, he shall not
say that I am wearing the willow, but I
wonder what he sees in that little, nasty,
idiot, Nancy King—yet report declares that
he is with her constantly. (Stuffs note
under the sofa _pillow and assumes a dignified attitude).
(Portiere swung aside and enter Mr. Conrad Dulaney. He holds out both hands)—
My dear Miss Howard—Miss Imogen, this
is joy.
Miss Howard takes only one hand and
coldly motions him to a seat at the opposite
side of the table.
Mr. Dulaney (feeling snubbed)—I---you
see I am here—you received my note?
Miss Howard (indifferently)—Your note!
oh yes, asking if I would be at home this
afternoon; you know I always am, at this
hour.
Mr. Dulaney (aside)—By Jove! how unconcerned. (Aloud)—But, Miss Imogen, I
hoped that you would give orders to admit
me alone.
Miss Howard—Why, really, Mr. Dulaney,
one cannot very well give out generally that
one is at home at five, and then refuse admittance to anybody; can one?
Mr. Dulaney—Under some circumstances.
I wanted particularly to see yau this afternoon.
Miss Howard (demurely)—And so, perhaps, might others.
Mr. Dulaney—Doubtless, but still—Oh!
dear, Miss Howard, you surely remember
last summer. Think of our two heavenly

weeks at Bar harbor! and of my following
you to Narragansett. Think of—
Miss Howard (interrupting)—Yes, I cannot soon forget Bar Harbor; it is just the
place for a generally all-round good time.
So many men! I wonder what becomes of
them in the winter?
Mr. Dulaney (sarcastically)—Frozen stiff,
poor devils, by the summer girls when they
meet again!
Miss Howard (indignantly)—How I hate
that term, "summer girl." It only means
someone with whom to flirt.
Mr. Dulaney—More probably someone who
does the flirting. Does it not?
Miss Howard (argumentatively) — Not
necessarily; but I despise the expression, it
is so hackneyed. More monotonous even
than "fin-du-seicle" or "up-to-date."
Mr. Dulaney—Pardon me for using it then.
But, Miss Howard, you give me small encouragement to tell you the secret that is
trembling upon my lips.
Miss Howard (pretending surprise)—The
secret? Yes, you mentioned you had one.
But I thought that it was man's perogative
to keep secrets, while only woman loved to
tell.
Mr. Dulaney—Some secrets are never
pleasant save when enjoyed with another.
Miss Howard—You limit the enjoyment.
A secret to be thoroughly appreciated should
be told to at least a dozen, always with the
injunction "never breathe it to a soul."
Mr. Dulaney—But at all events some secrets must be shared by two at first, must
they not?
Miss Howard (aside)—It is coming; I
must brace up. (Aloud)—I suppose so; but
why tell a third?
Mr. Dulaney (confused)—A third? I
don't understand. But, Imogen, you are so
different—so strange.
Miss Howard—"Imogen!" Pray, Mr. Dulaney, when did I lose my surname?
Mr. Dulaney—Excuse me; surely when we
took our moonlight sails you allowed me
the privilege of calling you by that dear
name, "Imogen." And I, too, was only
Conrad,
Miss Howard (scornfully)—How reminiscent you have become. You remind me
of Aunt Ann: "In such and such a year we
did thus and so."

Mr. Dulaney (angrily)—Thanks; knowing
the opinion you have of your aunt, I am
flattered, I am sure.
Miss Howard (also angrily)—What opinon have I of my aunt? Well, truly, Mr.
Dulaney, is it good taste to abuse my relations or discuss my likes or dislikes?
Mr. Dulaney—Again I ask your pardon.
It seems to be the only thing that you allow
me to ask this afternoon.
Miss Howard (making a brave struggle
to be funny)—Oh! ask for a cup of tea. I
am afraid I have not been very hospitable.
I should have offered it at once; see the
water boils nicely.
Mr. Dulaney—Thanks, very much; I never
take tea.
Miss Howard (forgetting her role)—You
told me at Narragansett that you perfectly
adored tea, and that you would often drop
in for it this winter on your way up town
from the office.
Mr. Dulaney (much pleased)—You do remember Narragansett, then?
Miss Howard (recovering herself)—Yes,
surely; I met Charlie Kidder there, don't
you know? and he was devoted to me.
Mr. Dulaney (losing his self-control fearfully)—Dash Charlie Kidder! Oh I do
hope that you did not hear me. Pardon
again, but I so thoroughly despise that chap,
a regular sissy with his feminine voice and
his vivid waistcoats and gorgeous ties!
Miss Howard (trying to look severe)—I
did hear your horrible language, and consider that it is most fortunate that Aunt Ann
is not about.
Mr. Dulaney (smiling)—There I agree
with you; but Miss Imogen, don't be cross
Miss Howard (staving off the news till she
has fortified herself with another cup of tea)
—Oh! by the way, are you interested in
politics, and for whom will you vote?
Mr. Dulaney (amazed at the change of
subject)—Surely every man is in these days:
but I did not know that you cared. Last
summer you used to assure me that a good
bicycle or a stylish modiste was of far more
consequence than a good President.
Miss Howard (coyly)—That was before I
met Mr. Du Pine. You know he is a great
gun in his party, and he has been coaching
me.

Mr. Dulaney (jealously)—Du Pine! Does
that old fossil visit you? He ought to be
preparing for another and a better world.
Miss Howard (pleased to have provoked
wrath)—Well, really, is visiting me a bar
to future happiness? So like a man to make
fun of any one cleverer than himself. Now
I never get angry when I hear of a woman'
who is better looking.
Mr. Dulaney (happily)—You never hear
of one.
Miss Howard (much appeased)—Thanks;
you shall have three lumps of sugar and
five pieces of lemon for your politeness.
Mr. Dulaney (laughing)—Spare me. But,
11!Iiss Howard, won't you listen to my secret,
or have you guessed it?
Miss Howard (with dignity)—It is not
hard to guess what the whole town is discussing.
Mr. Dulaney (surprised) — The whole
town! Why, Imogen—
Miss Howard—Again I must remind you
that I am only "Imogen" to my family and
dearest friends.
Mr. Dulaney (mortified)—Kidder and Du
Pine, I suppose. I can only beg your forgiveness for my presumption, yet, Miss Howard, you have changed towards me; now
last summer—
Miss Howard—Still harping upon last
summer. Is the present nothing, Mr. Dulaney, that you should forever dwell upon
the past?
Mr. Dulaney (epigrammatically) — The
past often times makes the present.
Miss Howard—Did you get that out of a
book, or make it up? It sounds like Mr.
Du Pine.
Mr. Dulaney (in a temper)—Unfortunately, I "made it up,' as you say; but if it suggests that ass Du Pine, I will promise you
never to repeat it.
Miss Howard (meditatively)—If it was
not too ridiculous, I should imagine that
you were jealous.
Mr. Dulaney (gloomily)—I have no right
to be jealous, have I?
Miss Howard (stiffly)—I am sure I do not
know what rights you have.
Mr. Dulaney (rising)—Well, it is useless
to prolong this conversation; I see that you
do not wish me to speak.
Miss Howard (aside)—He must not think

that; I must be brave. (Aloud)—Indeed, you
are mistaken; I wish very much to hear your
secret. You said that you were in love and
hoped soon to be engaged to the "sweetest
girl in the world." Of course, it is easy to
tell who she is—
Mr. Dulaney (coming nearer)—Of course

Miss Howard (endeavoring to steady her

Really! (aside)—Confound it, I don't understand her; is she making fun of me?

THE BALTIMORE CONCERT.
The date of the Musical Clubs' concert has
at last been definitely announced, posters are
out, tickets are on sale, and everyone on the
clubs is engaged in putting on the extra
finishing touches which are necessary for the
most important concert of the season. At
any time of day the passer-by may hear the
strains of fair music proceeding from the
windows of McCoy or Hopkins Halls, for the
clubs are practicing almost continuously.
The Glee Club is in excellent shape; this
year's aggregation numbers some of the best
voices that have ever been at Hopkins, and
the songs are particularly good. Among
them are:"The University Ode," with which
the concert will probably open; an old English ballad, entitled "A Franklynne's Dogge
Jumped Over a Style," which possesses much
attraction; "Hoo Wah Hoo, or the Tale of
the Western Desperado," to say the least,
exciting; "Jenks' Compound;" a stein song
by Mendelssohn, and a number of others. A
quartette, consisting of Messrs. Adkins,
Haughton, Holmes, and Ruth will be a feature; and it is said that Mr. Bristol has a
surprise in the way of some new song
"stunts."
The Mandolin Club has a repertoire no
less varied than that of the Glee Club: the
1905 Medley, which contains a little of everything that has caught the popular ear this
winter— "Katunka," "Blue Bell," "Uncle
Sammy," and many others. In addition to
the regular members of the club, Mr. Snowden has consented to drum the drum, Mr.
Ruth will try the triangle and Mr. Whittle
will flute the flute and blow the French horn.
The resulting orchestral effects should be
highly pleasing.
It was very unfortunate last year that the
fire occurred just before the concert; for a
time, indeed, things looked as if there would
be no concert at all. No such disturbing
circumstances have arisen this year, however,
and there is every reason to believe that the
coming event will be a great success.
As usual, the support of the alumni as
well as of the students is solicited. At the
time of the University of Virginia concert
here this spring, the active co-operation of
the Maryland alumni of that University was

noteworthy. Hopkins graduates, dwelling
under the very shadow of the Alma Mater,
should not prove less loyal.

DEBATE WITH BROWN
The eyes of the student body are eagerly
focused upon the date of April 8, when the
Black and Blue standard will be raised
against the forces of two leading universities.
In the afternoon our doughty twelve will
match their physical strength against that
of the University of Pennsylvania lacrosse
squad, while in the evening, in McCoy Hall,
the Hopkins debaters will meet Brown University upon the rostrum.
It will be remembered that we defeated
Brown last year in debate, but as the latter
is confident of wresting the laurels from us
this year, the coming contest will doubtless
be a spirited one. The question to be discussed is the same as that which was argued
in the inter-class debate, viz.: "Resolved,
That the economic and political interests of
the United States demand the permanent retention of the Philippine Islands."
Upon that occasion the audience and
judges were convinced by the winning
Juniors that an affirmative view should be
taken of this question, and it is "up to" our
team, in the coming debate, to reverse this
conviction, since we now have the negative
side. The men selected to represent Hopkins have already won their spurs. They
are: Messrs. Thomas De C. Ruth, Joseph T.
Singewald, L. Edwin Goldman (chairman),
and Ormond W.Hammond,alternate (sec'y).
The Brown team will consist of: Messrs.
George Hurley, Frederick Eugene Hawkins,
George Gershon Shor, and Lester Leopold,
Falk, alternate. The New Englanders will
reach Baltimore about noon Friday, and will
leave for home on Sunday.
Each debater will speak twice, the negative, instead of the affirmative, leading off
in the second round. Mr. French has been
working hard with our men ever since the
inter-class debate, and he shares the general
confidence that the team will put up a good
fight.
An attractive program of catchy selections
has been arranged by the Musical Clubs,
with which to intersperse the weighty de-

liberations of the speakers. Extra care (and
extra funds) will be used to have the hall
tastefully decorated, as the occasion will be
a social event. More palms will be used and
in many ways the display will differ from the
usual arrangements.

Barnett will take charge of Dr. Hollander's
classes during his absence.

faculty were present at the banquet.

EDITORIAL.
It is to be doubted if many of the persons
who have been charmed during the past fortnight by Dr. Woodberry's lectures know
that the course which they have been attending is part of one of the world's greatest
foundations for lectures on poetry. The
Turnbull foundation ranks at least second in
the English-speaking world—perhaps it
would be safe to say the world at large. Only
a similar foundation at Oxford University
can claim to be the peer of the Turnbull
lectureship, and this surpasses it only in
point of age. Though the Turnbull foundation is a comparatively recent one, it has already advanced to a commanding position.
To be asked to deliver the annual series is an
honor which any literateur of the world
would count a distinction.
The able way in which Mr. Woodberry has
filled the position this year is proof of the
wisdom of the authorities in choosing him.
Dr. Woodberry is himself a poet of no mean
ability, as one of his poems, printed elsewhere in this issue, will prove. With the
intuition of the poet he combines the clear
insight and broad grasp of subject of the
trained critic; and his course has proved well
worthy to take its place among the illustrious
courses which have preceded it.
Although the two games which have been
played by the baseball nine have not been
especially encouraging yet, on the whole, the
prospects for a good team seem fairly bright.

The opening game was hardly a just test,
from the fact that it was the first time that
the men had played together out of doors.
In spite of this, the nine showed up to good
advantage, and won by a comfortable score.
The second game was a decided disappointment, for although Hopkins seemed to experience more than her share of bad luck,
yet the result can not be accounted for in this
way. Individual play was as much to blame
as lack of team work, and the men seemed to
be "off their game," so to speak. However,
it is much better for a slump to occur at the
beginning of the season, when it can be rectified, than at the end. The material at
Hopkins for a winning nine is for the most
part good, and a little more outdoor practice
will doubtless round out the team into excellent shape. The pitcher's box is a matter which is still giving some worry, so the
outlook will be much brighter when it is
satisfactorily decided. The team has a long
schedule before it, yet on the whole, it seems
to be quite probable that it will be a successful one.
The prospects for the Musical Clubs next
year have not hitherto seemed very bright;
it was difficult to see how any of the clubs
were to be kept up to the present standard,
and the very existence of the Banjo Club
seemed to be a matter of doubt. In such
a state of affairs it is with a decided feeling
of hopefulness that most of the under-graduates will read the letter on the subject in
this issue from Manager Pagon, who takes
a more optimistic view of the outlook. By
calculating up the players from various
sources who will compose the Mandolin and
Glee Clubs next winter, he reaches the conclusion that the Mandolin Club should be
at least as large as it is this year, and that
the prospects for the Glee Club are even
better.
With the Banjo Club conditions are not
so promising, however, and its future seems
to be in the hands of the Freshmen. Only
one man will be left in the club when the
practice begins next fall, so that the only
way that the club can be kept up is by several men taking lessons on the banjeaurine
during the summer. "There are," Mr.
Pagon says, "at least eleven men on the
other two Clubs who would find it very little

7

THE NEWS-LETTER.
trouble to take lessons on the banjeaurine.
Indeed, they should be made to do so—and
no undergraduate should be allowed to go
on the trips unless he belongs to at least
two clubs."
This is an admirable suggestion, and if
matters can be so arranged as to make these
men learn to play the banjeaurine and also
to encourage several Freshmen to learn to
play the same instrument, the success of the
next year's Banjo Club is assured. A slight
difficulty is encountered in the fact that if
the rule is made that no one shall be taken
on the trips unless he belongs to at least
two clubs, it will tend to discourage any of
the present Freshman class who might be
Inclined to take lessons on the banjeaurine
this summer from doing so, if they did not
already play another instrument. But the
advantages from such a rule would probably
outweigh the disadvantages, and we recommend it for consideration to the powers that
govern the output of musical talent at the
University.

Y. M. C. A.
At the second biennial conference of the
Associations in Maryland, Delaware and the
District of Columbia, held at Annapolis,
March 24-26, Johns Hopkins was represented
by eleven delegates. The conference was a
most successful one; and each delegate of
the total one hundred and fifty could get
something for his own benefit. The delegates
were royally entertained in the Annapolis
homes, and found this one of the best features of the conference. A special session
for college men was held Saturday afternoon.
Other meetings put the college men in touch
with the Association work in other departments. The most notable addresses were
those of Governor Warfield and Rev. John
Timothy Stone. The Hopkins delegates
were: Boyer, Bird, Fenby, Gould, Glenn and
Lips, of 1907; Curley, Gressitt and Middleton, of 1906; and Glocker and Addison, of
the graduate department. Ask any one of
them for impressions of the conference.
The committee on the Northfield Student
Conference is now beginning work, with W.
R. Straughn, '05, as chairman. Northfield,
a quaint New England village, with an edu-

cational institution known throughout our
land, is situated in the northwestern part of
Massachusetts, about twenty-four hours' distance from Baltimore. It is an ideal place
for conferences, and for many summers past,
the great student conference, with delegates
from all the leading institutions of our Eastern States, has been held there. Last year,
over six hundred were in attendance. The
opportunities open to one who is a member
of such a convention, the advantages of association with so many of the leaders in all
branches of college activity, the ten days'
life in camp, the spiritual and physical recreation afforded—all these things will the
committee set before the student body at an
early date.
The conference will take place this year
June 30 to July 9, inclusive. Every student
who believes in religious work should consider Northfield before completing his plans
for the coming summer. Yale sends more
than a hundred men each year; Harvard
sends fifty to seventy; Pennsylvania, about
forty. Cannot fifteen or twenty Hopkins
men find time to take advantage of this opportunity ?
Watch for further announcements.

ACE HIGH.
The king of hearts had a daughter,
The queen of hearts was she;
And over all of her subjects,
She ruled most graciously.'
Now the knave of hearts was her lover,
And a lover fond was he;
But the king ruled over his daughter,
And ruled most cruelly.
"I can take them both," said the father,
"Send each to far different parts;
No more can they love each other,
I win," cried the king of hearts.
But in spite of his firm refusal,
The queen and the knave eloped;
And the end of the match was lovely
—Much better than either had hoped.
Yes, the end of the match was lovely,
No danger they had to face;
For now that the pair were one, you see,
The king was ruled by the ace!

THE NEWS-LETTER.

HOPKINS, 13; ROCK HILL, 2.
The baseball season began auspiciously on
Saturday, March 25, with an easy victory
over Rock Hill College, by 13 to 2 A large
party of rooters accompanied the team to
Ellicott City, and if appearances count for
anything, got considerable pleasure out of
the trip, though the contest itself was never
close enough to produce "excitement's blissful thrill."
Hopkins practically won the game in the
first inning. MacGuinness, Rock Hill's pitching "star," appeared to have slipped his
orbit at the start, and before he settled down
Hopkins had rolled up eight runs. After
that, runs were "no object," and the five
which were afterward added to the University's score were the result of chance rather
than of purpose.
The chief interest to Hopkins rooters lay
in the fact that the game furnished an excellent opportunity for judging of the ability
of the various candidates for the team. The
fine pitching of Waring and Higgins firnished especial cause for satisfaction. It had
been feared that the nine this year would be
weak in the box, but the showing of these
two twirlers effectually dispelled this fear.
Waring pitched the first seven innings and
allowed but three hits, all of which would
have been easy outs on a better diamond.
Higgins, who was in the box the last two
innings, struck out four men in this short
time and allowed but one hit, also due to
the grounds.
Lyon made a beautiful play in the seventh,
with a one-hand catch of a wild throw to
third. Brown, at first base, was a tower of
strength, accepting thirteen chances without.

an error. Captain McDonnell fully lived up
to his reputation both in the field and at bat.
Randall played a strong and heady game behind the plate, while Bowie put up his usual
good game at third. Iglehart and Goldman
did so well in center and left fields respectively that they were given these positions
permanently. Preston had no chances in
right field, but proved somewhat of a disappointment at bat. The batting, indeed of the
whole team was below what it should have
been, due in large measure, perhaps, to the
lack of necessity to make runs.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

ST. JOHNS, 10; HOPKINS, 7.
The Hoodoo which always lurks about the
athletic field at St. John's College upon the
occasions of Hopkins visits thither, made its
usual appearance last Saturday and achieved
its usual success. Last spring St. John's
won out in the ninth inning; last fall its
eleven scored the touchdown which won
from Hopkins in the last thirty seconds of
play. This time the eighth inning witnessed
the advent of the Hoodoo.
At the beginning of this inning the score
stood 7 to 5 in favor of Hopkins. Waring
appeared invincible and the game seemed
certainly won. Then the Hoodoo took a
.hand. Four errors followed each other in
grim procession; Waring was seized with a
panic and struck two batters; then St. John's
awoke to its opportunities and "added wreck
to ruin" by smashing out a single and a
three-bagger. Five runs was the net result
of the stampede. The best Hopkins could
do in the sole inning which remained was to
go out in one, two, three order. Verily, we
had "met the enemy and we were their'n'
the Hoodoo's.
Sonie persons who saw the game were inclined to believe that the real name of the
Hoodoo was Demoralization. It may be so,
but the NEws-LETTER's "correspondent at
the front" does not believe so. There was
a child-like simplicity and lack of purpose
about the whole thing which to his mind
was inevitably suggestive of the supernatural. Past experience strengthens this view,
and loyalty applauds it. The NEWS-LETTER
still holds the high opinion of the nine to
which the Rock Hill victory gave rise. But
mind, gentlemen of the diamond, no more
Hoodoos!

LACROSSE OUTLOOK.
Johns Hopkins is on the eve of another
lacrosse season. Never in the history of our
connection with the game has the actual
strength of the team been so much a matter
of speculation as it is this year. Until the
first game has been played even the coaches
will have hardly more than an incomplete
idea upon this head.
The reason for this lies in the fact that
such a large proportion of the men will be
new. . Out of last year's twelve, only five
men—Blanck, Meyer, Dill, Morse and Strob-

9

har—will again be in the line-up. Of course,
the veteran "Bill" Schmeisser is by no
means a "new man," but the fact remains
that half at least, of the positions will have
to be filled by men who never played on a
'Varsity team before. The squad as a whole
has showed up well in practice, however, and
the large infusion of new blood may not
prove a permanent weakness.
The personnel of the team is also a matter
of guess-work. The large number of the
candidates has made the task of selecting the
team a difficult one, and the coaches have
thought it best to go very slowly in so important a particular. The exact line-up for
the opening game will scarcely be known
until the men make their appearance on the
field; and this line-up is not expected to remain through the season unaltered.
One thing, at least, however, should be
very plain to all. That is that every student is expected to attend every game.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

AN OPEN LETTER.
Wednesday, March 15, 1905.
[To the Editors of the NEWS-LETTER.]
Gentlemen:—
I have often heard it said that next year
the Musical Clubs will be very poor owing to
the lack of players. But the scarcity of men
will not be so great as has been thought. The
Glee Club will lose only three men, leaving
twenty-two to start the year with. Out of
this year's Mandolin Club fifteen men will
be back. But the prospects of the Club are
even better than would seem to be indicated
by this. In the Junior and Freshman
classes are four or five men who for some
reason or other, have not come out this year,
but who play fairly well. In the Medical
School is one man who led the club at Yale,
and another who led the Bowdoin Club, besides a number who have played at Yale,
Princeton, and elsewhere. In addition to
these are four or five players at the Latin
School who expect to enter this June. These,
with the old men, will make up a club of
twenty-five or twenty-six men, which is as
large as the Club this year. There is, evidently, therefore, no need of worrying over
the Mandolin and Glee Clubs. With the
Banjo Club, however, conditions are different, for next year only one man will be left.
Yet this is not an insurmountable difficulty,
for two years ago the same conditions existed and were overcome. Only one man
was left prom the year before. But during
the spring and summer four Juniors took
lessons on the banjeaurine, and the five, together with one Freshman and one graduate
of the year before, have made up the Club
for two years. There is no reason why this
cannot be repeated. In the other two Clubs
are at least eleven men who would find it
very little trouble to take lessons on the banjeaurine or the guitar during the summer.
Indeed, they should be made to do so, and
no undergraduate should be allowed to go
on any of the different trips unless he belongs to at least two clubs. These eleven
men could make a club every bit as good
as the one this year if they would only work.
If need be the trustees of the University
might be asked for fifty or seventy-five, dollars with which to pay a teacher.

But whatever is done, have a Banjo Club,
even though it consists of only five or six
men. A small club that plays well is every
bit as good as a large one that plays poorly.
In the year 1892 the Mandolin Club consisted of .only four men: two mandolins, one
banjo and one guitar. But there is no need
of having a small club, for if every one will
work, a club of fifteen or sixteen can be
gotten together which will be all the better
for the work having been expended in building it up.
Sincerely Yours,
W. WATTERS PAGON.

IRRESISTABLE.
Oh I wrote a poem to Polly,
And another one to Bess,
And I made some verse for Molly,
And again some more for Tess;
Oh a sonnet did for Letty,
And a rondel sweet for Nell,
And a quatrain short for Hetty,
And a song for Isabel;
Yet although they liked my powers,
In the most poetic arts,
Yet the man who sent them flowers,
Was the man that won their hearts.
—Saw I flowers growing cheaper,
Thought that I would go down deeper.
So no more I write to Polly,
And no more to pretty Bess,
So no verses send to Molly,
And no rhymes to winsome Tess;
So no sonnets make for Letty,
And no rondels sweet for Nell,
So no quatrains short for Hetty,
And no songs for Isabel;
Yet they say that I'm a "dandy,"
Know full well the best of arts,
—Now the man that sends them candy,
Is the man that wins their hearts.
'06.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

THE MEDICAL SCHOOL.
The Trustees have elected Dr. Lewellys
Franklin Barker to be Professor of Medicine.
Professor Barker is a native of Canada and
graduated in medicine in the University of
Toronto in 1890. The following year he
held the position of House Officer in the
Toronto General Hospital, and he was then
successively an assistant physician and assistant resident pathologist in the Johns
Hopkins Hospital. He was Fellow in Anatomy in the University for two years, Associate and Associate Professor of Anatomy
from 1894 to 1899, and Associate Professor
of Pathology during the year 1899-1900. In
1899 he visited the Philippine Islands as one
of the Medical Commissioners representing
this University. During the past five years
he has held the post of Professor and head of
the Department of Anatomy in the University of Chicago and in the Rush Medical College. In 1901 he was appointed by the Secretary of the Treasury a member of the
special commission to determine the existence or non-existence of plague in San Francisco.
His published works include "The Nervous System and its Constituent Neurones,"
a translation of Werner Spalteholz's "Hand
Atlas of Human Anatomy," and numerous
monographs and addresses.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

Notes From All the Colleges.
That Japan is strictly up to date pretty
much everyone is willing to admit, but it
has gotten further than most people suspect.
The island has a baseball association, and the
team of the Waseda University has won the
championship. Not content with a national
championship, the team is looking for other
worlds to conquer, and has challenged the
team of the Stanford University for a series
of games to be played in San Francisco. It
even looks as if the games may be arranged,
and if Waseda can make a good showing
it will receive the congratulations of the
American people. Baseball is thoroughly
American, exclusively, we should say, were
it not rash to attempt to prejudge what the
versatile and athletic Japanese have been
able to do with the Waseda nine.
—Intercollegiate.

In spite of an increase of 13 per cent, in
student attendance within the last year, the
University of Pennsylvania is beginning to
experience the same difficulty as Harvard
and Yale in making its fixed income and
gifts meet the running expenses.
Considerable discussion has been aroused
at the University of Pennsylvania over a bill
introduced in the State Legislature making
college hazing a misdemeanor. The university has already made every member of the
sophomore and freshman classes sign an
agreement, as a part of their matriculation,
not to participate in hazing.

The quarter-decennial class book of the class
of 1878, of Yale, just published, repeats the
evidence that academic married couples fail
By the provision of the will of the late to reproduce themselves in the census. The
John C. Coombs, class of 1869, Bowdoin has 97 marriages in the class are represented by
the promise of a substantial bequest, prob- only 179 living children.
ably aggregating $100,000.
The cost of college athletics is always a
subject in order. Interesting light is cast
on the subject by the report of the Yale
financial union, showing that at that institution last year $75,174 was expended in
connection with athletic events. Of this,
football required $26,996; baseball, $15,179;
the boat club, $16,626; the athletic association, $7,221, and maintenance of grounds,
$9,150. Despite this heavy outlay, the athletic association closed the season with a
balance of $31,222, football proving the
greatest winner, with a net profit of $44,000.

The State College of Pennsylvania has a
national bank. One hundred and five depositors have opened accounts amounting to
$18,100.
"Jiu Jitsu" has been taken up quite extensively at the University of Pennsylvania,
and a course in this science has been made
compulsory at Annapolis.
Andrew Carnegie has donated $16,700 to
St. John's College for the building of a new
laboratory.
